ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Furthering my Spanish reading, writing, and listening skills, particularly in terms of confidence of grammar structuring.
Advanced Spanish conversational and grammatical skills. Learned tons of new vocabulary, as well as polished grammatical themes and concepts learned previously in L3.

I learned how to better speak Spanish. I am able to write in Spanish pretty well, but this class really worked on my speaking skills. Every student had to participate vocally in class. This was challenging, but it got easier with practice.
Spanish language skills, knowledge of culture and history of Spanish-speaking countries.
I learned to proficiently speak, write and read Spanish in a small group.
I have learned a wide variety of new grammar structures,
A better understanding of the Spanish language as well as cultural insights and grammar concepts.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There were no apparent weaknesses. The workload was both more managable than L3 Spanish, while also being sufficient for practice, preparation, and developing new skills, as well as being very highly organized.
Strength is that it had a lot of varied content so was never boring. Weakness is that during virtual format, it isn't as good for discussions.
The strengths were that the course was very well organized and a majority of the material felt very relevant to the topics we were learning about. No outstanding weaknesses come to mind.

Strengths: highly structured, useful content, diversity of educative media (songs, poetry, films, YouTube videos, etc.); Weaknesses: I needed more time to digest the grammar, use them, and make connections between all of them; I also needed more opportunities to force myself to spontaneously speak.
Definitely hard to learn spanish online so more effort to verbally practice and learn vocab would have helped.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Encouraged interaction and breakout rooms during class hours facilitated a cohesive learning environment that took advantage of the online learning situatuon as best as it could have.
I thought that this class adjusted well. Having zoom classes created an environment similar to an in-person Spanish class.
The powerpoints and discussions succeeded.

I enjoyed the flexibility and the instructor's attentiveness to everyone's participation; I think it was too easy for students to use Spanish Dictionary on the side, which made it more difficult for us to engage spontaneously

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this to someone who chose Spanish as their designated language requirement.
Yes, I feel that it is important to learn how to fluently speak another language. This class is very helpful.
Yes, for those who want to improve their Spanish as well as learn about Spanish-speaking countries.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to reach a high level of proficiency in Spanish.
Yes, I think Level 4 Spanish really takes your grasp of grammar to the next level. If you fully digest and can use everything taught in class, you should be able to express most common phrases.
If you are looking to progress in Spanish, this course will force you to learn, adapt and apply what you know and build and solidify your spanish foundation.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We would meet on zoom for class on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. Tuesdays and Thursdays would be asynchronous days.
Seminar-style classes on M/W/F; daily homework; rest days or exam days on T/Th
